He did tell my twin and me one or two anecdotes.
I think practically all the survivors of that

2710.text: nightmare chose not to speak about it.

2719.text:
I've written a lot of poems about him now
and I think that's partly to make up for not

2726.text:
having talked to him. He was a very beautiful
man I realise that now. And he was wise. Despite

2739.text:
the fact he read the Daily Mail and the News
of the World.

2749.text:
- You've published a beautiful poem about
him in the London Review of Books I think

2759.text:
Oh I couldn't read that poem, you know? It's
an unendurable poem for me.

2770.text:
He died in summer 1960 and I was home from
Trinity College for Easter, just a few months

2782.text:
before he died. My first poem had appeared
in Icharus the college magazine and it was

2791.text:
called Marigolds - 'She gave him marigolds
the colour of Autumn/ To keep in his cold

2800.text:
room/ And the late light of Autumn/ Gilded
all their moments'.

2806.text:
A rather limp-wristed piece, and the last
person I wanted to find it was my father.

2814.text:
Well, he did discover it and he said 'Michael,
it's not worth the paper it's printed on'.

2824.text:
Which might have been true, but he shouldn't
have said that, but he was in pain. I was

2833.text:
telling a group of schoolkids this story.
In 2001, I was in Buckingham Palace receiving

2842.text:
the Queen's Gold Medal from the Queen and
I showed her a photography of my father receiving

2854.text:
the Military Cross from George V and I said
'May I show you this photograph of my father

2860.text:
receiving a medal from your grandfather'.
And she was very taken with it. I said may

2868.text:
I ask where the spot is and she said 'At the
back'. It made me think of a patio and a barbecue

2877.text:
out the back! I said 'May I go there?'. She
said 'After the audience I will arrange for

2889.text:
my equerry to take you there'. She did and
I was able to work out from the balustrade

2897.text:
the exact spot where my father had stood getting
his medal for gallantry and I was getting

2902.text:
my medal for poetry and I thought inwardly
to myself that Marigolds wasn't such an awful

2922.text:
- What is it about the Iliad that you like
so much?

2930.text:
You haven't read it? Oh, I envy you. I envy
you the first time. It's the greatest poem

2940.text:
that I know. The greatest about war and death.
But especially death. It's endless and bottomless

2950.text:
and I feel that poetry changed. It can't go
on, poetry always has to change. But it didn't

2964.text:
get any better, after The Iliad. Nothing's
better than The Iliad. The same way that music

2972.text:
had to change after Bach, which it did. But
it didn't get any better. Anyway, may I recommend

2986.text:
- More questions please. Yes, also at the
back.

2998.text:
As Michael said, although I'm Irish, I feel
Irish and I was inconsolable a few weeks ago

3010.text:
when England beat Ireland at rugby. So, I'm
Irish but I'm true to the Britannic side.

3019.text:
To the British side. My grandparents were
Londoners and I never met my father's father.

3032.text:
He was a journeyman carpenter. And I only
met my grandpa George, my mother's father,

3039.text:
two or three times. Although he left a vivid
impression, he was very cockney and a bit

3053.text:
of a show-off. Grandpa George. Not the softest
human being I've ever known.

3064.text:
So that's a gap. The marvellous thing about
grandparenthood is you acquire a new title.

3074.text:
You acquire new titles you know? Papa and
Granddad. It's like being promoted for doing

3084.text: nothing. I think someone had a hand up there.

3092.text:
- What made you start writing? What were your
inspirations.

3098.text:
Well, I was about 16. That huge explosion,
you know? Of gonads. And hair. And the aesthetic

3112.text:
awakening. It was those two things - sexual
and aesthetic awakening. And discovering big

3120.text:
heavy Thames and Hudson books in the school
library and looking at Van Gogh and Monet

3128.text:
and Toulouse-Lautrec and all the great french
painters. Discovering that. Going to the Ulster

3137.text:
Hall to hear, it was called the City of Belfast
Orchestra. And discovering Sibelius and LP

3148.text:
records had just, we'd moved from 78s to LP
records and I spent all my pocket money on

3159.text:
classical music records. Some jazz. And I
discovered Keats. And girls. And in order

3170.text:
to impress the girls I wrote poems. It was
not a successful exercise and then once you've

3185.text:
done it, who is it talks about the fascination
of, Yeats, the fascination of what's difficult.

3195.text:
The struggle. The exploration through words
of a vaguely apprehended notion. That seems

3205.text:
to me what it's about. And the first time
you do that, you're hooked. The great Irish

3210.text:
poet Patrick Kavanagh said 'A young man dabbles
in verses, to discover that they have become

3220.text:
his life'. Couldn't put it any better than
that.

3232.text:
- You are part of a constellation of great
Northern Irish poets and you read us some

3254.text:
wonderful elegiac poems tonight. To your twin
and to your father. I wondered if we might

3262.text:
expect some kind of elegy to Seamus Heaney
on the horizon?

3266.text:
Well, when Seamus died I was wakened up in
the morning by a local radio station and they

3278.text:
said 'Have you heard Seamus Heaney has died?'.
I said 'No'. And she said 'Would you care

3285.text:
to say a few words?'. I said 'No'. But I had
written a poem, I can read you a little cluster

3300.text:
of poems, oh no, perhaps I can't really, no,
but I wrote a poem with Seamus and I getting

3310.text:
degrees in UCD in Dublin and there was a big
dinner afterwards. Luncheon. A luncheon! Such

3321.text:
a marvellously pretentious word, isn't it?
Michael and I had luncheon today. And Seamus

3330.text:
leaned down the table and he says 'What's
the greek for boat?'. And do you know you

3339.text:
have these blackouts? Well, there was I in
this learned company and I pretend to be a

3345.text:
translator of Homer. I couldn't remember.
Skathos of course. But I couldn't remember.

3352.text:
So, I was so embarassed that I wrote a poem
called 'Boat' for Seamus. And then I went

3363.text:
to visit his grave. I'd gone to his funeral
but not to the graveyard in Bellaghy. So I

3368.text:
went some months later and I wrote a little
six line poem to go with 'Boat'. I shall read

3377.text:
them shall I? Because, I really loved Seamus,
you know, and I miss him. And I put these

3385.text:
in the Irish Times as a kind of partway to
an elegy, but I don't know, everyone's writing

3401.text:
elegies for Seamus and I never like doing
what everyone else is doing. I never have.

3414.text:
The first is about eight lines long, called
'Boat', it's a little squib. Although Marie

3421.text:
Heaney said it moved her to tears. And then
just a few weeks ago I wrote this little six

3431.text: liner and it quotes at the end Psalm 91.

3449.text:
Whatís the Greek for boat,
You ask, old friend,

3464.text:
Shingle-scrunching keel ñ
But, so close to home,

3472.text:
Thereís a danger always
Of amnesiac storms,

3486.text:
One wreath had blackberry clusters intertwined
Was it a blackbird or a wren

3495.text:
That briefly sang a graveside aria?
God-like in its way. A psalm.

3505.text:
He will defend you under his wing.
You will be safe under his feathers.
